LITTLE GIRL LAID OVER THE MUSCULATURE OF SOMETHING MORE

DON'T KNOW WHAT YOU'RE TALKING ABOUT
LUCY IS SITTING IN THE PASSENGER SEAT
LIMP, EYES FIXED IN A BLANK STARE.
IT'S NOT CHILD KILLING IF SHE'S NOT A
EMILY, AS A YOUNG GIRL, WITH HER MOTHER.

MOTION, VICIOUS AND MUSCLED AND SMELLING BLOOD.

LUCY IN A BATH ROBE BEHIND HER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young teacher (DARLA) chalks a lesson on a blackboard i sun-drenched Los Angeles classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and we know from yesterday that the base of a triangle times half the height equals the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl in the back row raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy's asleep again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darla puts down the chalk and comes up the aisle to where slight, fair-skinned girl in a thrift shop dress sleeps h down on her desk. The girl from the opening scene. LUCY SHERIDAN. Darla stands over her with obvious concern. Put a finger to her lips to quiet the giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws the shade. It drops a shadowbox on the sleeping girl. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A former gang member sitting with his wife and troubled e year-old son. The MARTINEZ FAMILY. A family in crisis. Sitting opposite is an LA County social worker. Twenties. Attractive but overworked. EMILY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would just go off, you know, start tearin' the place down. You didn't even know why he was doin' it half the time, you just got out of his way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what you learned from your father now Diego's learning from you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's painful for him to hear that. He loves his son, quit the streets for him. Overcome by emotion, he nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That really upsets you, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes his eyes on his tattooed arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cuz I mean I don't want him to be like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy looks at his father, has never seen him cry befor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the conference room, Emily musses the boy's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whole week without skipping school? Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles, nods. A glimpse of the boy he might have been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last time I make a bet with you. (to his parents) See you guys next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Martinez family heads down the hall, Diego lagging behind. Emily watches with guarded optimism, knowing thei chances. Then turns to the NEXT FAMILY, welcoming the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cut your hair. It looks great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hurried opening and closing of files reveals PHOTOS o abused children. Bruises. Cuts. Broken bones. Emily trying to locate a single case amid the stacks and clutte her desk. An angry mother SCREAMING at her on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is trying to steal your child, they found bruises and cigarette burns -- Mrs Lynch, I read the medical report -- well, if you feel you need legal representation that's perfectly within your rights...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flurry of obscenities followed by a dial tone. Emily pu the phone down. Sighs wearily.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: One less Christmas card for Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her supervisor WAYNE, forties, gay, leaning in the doorwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many active cases you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops another file on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, absolutely not, look at this, Wayne, look, I'm buried --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Em, we all are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off. Emily shoves the new file onto the shelf ab her desk. Looks at it guiltily. Takes it down again. Handwritten on the front: SHERIDAN, LUCY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens it. A school portrait of ten-year-old Lucy clip to the preliminary report. The sad face draws Emily in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old VOLVO WAGON skirts rush hour traffic on Wilshire. Faded red paint. Ski rack on the roof. An ancient bumpersticker says Educate. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IPod jacked into the car stereo playing hip alternative MUSIC, Emily leans on an elbow as she drives, not crazy a L.A. but at ease with herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily's red Volvo wagon turns in the drive of a single-pe home she rents in a working-class neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cozy. Her haven. Light colors offset dark hardwood floors Emily comes in, stack of files under her arm. Tired. Long day. Drops the files in a chair. Sprinkles some food in a fish tank. Referees through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fight. Hey, that's his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns on the tv. World news. Violence. People suffering. Turns it off. Puts on some quiet music. Hits play on her answering machine as she flops down barefoot on the sofa a magazine, peeling an orange, decompressing.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Suze, missed you at yoga the other day, give me a call.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hi, Em, Jackie, just checking in, hope you're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEEP. A charming male voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted, her career path questionable, her faith in mankind shaken, she resisted her tendency toward introspection and went to have a drink with her friend Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEEP. Emily gives a tired sigh. Faint smile under it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noisy, trendy downtown bar. Professional type on a bar stool. Thirties. Handsome. DOUG. He laughs when he sees Emily. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so in your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a kiss. Sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be honest. The whole psychology thing, it's just about scoring chicks, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regrettably, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a laugh. He gestures to the bartender for anot beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what freaks me out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you have a four-year degree and make seventeen grand a year after taxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sit there talking to these families, you know, like I'm some expert. My family's a train wreck. I mean, I had this moment today where I realized I might be totally full of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's full of it. In the end you're a number to call for people who don't have anyone else. There's no way that's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods, appreciates that. Recognizes a girl going by the crowd. A friend from school. Well-dressed. Career- oriented. The track Emily might be on if she weren't a social worker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Becca...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. So one of us is a major screwup, I can't remember if I was supposed to call you or the other way around...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's me, it's just been a crazy couple weeks. You remember Doug. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. (then to Emily) Listen, my ride's leaving, let's catch up soon, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods okay. The girl departs. Emily's beer arrives. Doug hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So anyway, I've done some soul searching and I just want to say that if a full-on relationship feels like too much right now, I'd be willing to consider a purely physical one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, sipping her beer, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you might actually enjoy yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I would, I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to explain. Doug saves her the trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, the job, you get home you don't have anything left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods yeah, leans in closer, the friendly banter giv way to a moment of real sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were anyone, it'd be you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange a look then Doug clinks his glass against h And as they drink together after a long day, more than friends, less than lovers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily in glasses, reading the Sheridan file on her bed. T preliminary report concerns her: "Socially withdrawn. Lac of appetite. Sleeping at school..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her gaze returns to Lucy's photo. Sadly, under her breath

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing to you? 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, rundown family home on a once-prosperous cul de s Emily pulls up. Gets out. Checks that she has the right address. Halfway up the walk something stops her dead in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: staring at her through one of the lacy white curtains upstairs. Ghostly pale. Gone as soon as she sees it. Emil stands frozen for a moment. Walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches to knock on the door and it opens abruptly, t security chain snapping taut. A woman's voice growls at h from the darkness inside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily Jennings. Child Services? We spoke on the phone...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peering through the crack is the pallid, bony face from t upstairs window. Lucy's mother. MARGARET SHERIDAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said the seventeenth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today is the seventeenth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday was the thirteenth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, rather amazed at the conversation she's having, ta a newspaper from her bag. Indicates the date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday was the fourteenth, that makes today the seventeenth. Monday the seventeenth. The date of our appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes in Emily's face. What the hell? Then we hear the chain unlock. It opens again. 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we get our first good look at Lucy's mother. Gaunt. Pale. Dark rings under her eyes. She steps aside, not welcoming Emily in, merely allowing her to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark, the curtains drawn. Margaret twitches one open begrudging courtesy. The house is tidy but sad, steeped i kind of puritanical gloom. Lucy peers down through the upstairs banister, anxious, unsure what's going on. Emily sees her, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come down, I'd like to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy hesitates, sensing her mother's disapproval. Comes slowly down the stairs. Emily shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Emily. What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty name. Pretty girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy turns shyly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there somewhere we can talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret sighs and heads down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, file in hand, trying to project professionalism in arm chair that tilts to one side. Margaret and Lucy sitti opposite on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you expect your husband back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we've found it's more beneficial if the whole family participates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's not home so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrugs again. 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any way of contacting him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I don't know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then we hear a POWER TOOL go on in the basement. Emi sensing the lie, indicates the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret averts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you ask him to join us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have anything to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you ask him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret weighs Emily's resolve, gives Lucy a cautionary glance then exits. We hear her open a door and holler int the basement over the noise of the power tool.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Edward! EDWARD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The power tool stops.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: That lady's here. From the state. She wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear an angry unintelligible reply.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I already told her, she wants to anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the power tool get thrown aside. FOOTSTEPS poundi up the cellar stairs. Emily's and Lucy's faces reflect th same simple fear. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy not so sure. The FOOTSTEPS are upon them. EDWARD SHERIDAN makes his entrance. A menacing man with a gaunt face and dark deep-set eyes. Emily holds out her hand. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Emily --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward forgoes the handshake, his contempt obvious. Sits beside Lucy on the sofa. Margaret sits on the other side. Lucy tenses, trapped between them. Emily speaks with kindness and composure. Hostile encounters part of the jo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here today because Lucy's school is concerned about changes they're seeing in her academic performance. The kinds of changes they're seeing are often associated with family problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward leans over and whispers something caustic in Margaret's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie says we don't have family problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just it, many times a family won't even know they're having problems until it's too late. That's where we come in. We help families communicate and learn healthier ways of resolving conflict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward whispers again in Margaret's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie says we don't need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Sheridan, is there some reason you won't speak to me directly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there some reason why your husband won't speak to me directly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret nods, gives Edward a look as though for permissi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie doesn't like speakin' out of anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily does well to hide her fear. Refusing to be intimidated, she engages Edward's stare. A battle of will But his gaze has a murderous intensity she can't match. S looks down, shuffling papers. Battle lost. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily follows Wayne along a row of cubicles after hours. He's dropping files on desks. The new cases never stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No laws against being weird, Em. Send it over to CMC, we'll do a follow-up in a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say weird, I said scary. The guy sat there the entire time staring at me, the mother is like his emotional slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne pauses in mock bewilderment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, did you just fly to New York and meet my parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne, this girl's in trouble. I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath Wayne's humor, a sober, hard-learned practicality

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna know what I can feel? The lawsuit we're gonna get hit with if we violate her parents' rights without any evidence they've done something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I talk to you you sound more like a lawyer, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, maybe because every time I make an emotional decision I get called by one. I'm sorry, you're gonna have to let this one go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put these files in front of me and you ask me to tell you what's going on. Well, I'm telling you, there's something going on and it's not something good. I've done my job, I've told you, what you do with it is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off. Wayne alone after hours with his conscienc 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open with a DING and Edward and Margar Sheridan step out in their Sunday best. Benevolent faces. Lucy between them, ribbon in her hair, brand new dress, appearing coached as she eats an ice cream cone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, disgusted by the charade, trades looks with the parents as they go past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gazing fondly at Lucy, Edward directs his comments at Way who sits opposite the family with Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They really are God's miracles. Day she was born was the happiest day of our lives. We're not perfect parents, we know that, but we figure if you let `em know how much you love `em a lot of the other stuff takes care of itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne nods his agreement. Edward puts his arm around Lucy for effect. Her eyes go to Emily. A silent plea for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Mr Sheridan, since you've suddenly acquired the power of speech, doesn't it concern you a little that Lucy's grades have gone from A's to D's in three months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course it does, she's our daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a glance Wayne cautions Emily about her tone of voic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you have no idea why she's falling asleep at school every day? Why she's not able to sleep at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward looks at Margaret, then Emily, affects bewildermen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad dreams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Wayne in private conversation. She's pissed off The Sheridan family in the other room, preparing to leave 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna be having bad dreams when he gets hit with child endangerment. (off Wayne's reluctance) Don't tell me you're buying this daddy's little girl routine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they're overcompensating a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little? Let me talk to her. Alone. She wants to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes. Talk to them about how much they love kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily walks with Lucy, looking for a way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew someone at school named Lucy, she was a writer. Do you ever write? I do sometimes, it helps me sort out how I'm feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy doesn't take the bait. She stops for a drink at a wa fountain. Emily bends for a sip after. Misfires. As she wipes her face, embarrassed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I just shot like a gallon of water up my nose. So much for establishing trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy smiles, for the first time. It's the opening Emily w looking for. Maintaining that precious eye contact,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening to you? I can help. Let me help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy looks away, eyes brimming with tears. 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lowers her head in shame, tears rolling down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they don't hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do. I hear them. They go in the cellar and talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sending me to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily's mouth falls open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've heard them say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods. As Emily registers this in quiet horror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tape recorder is running. Emily and Wayne alone with Lu She's hesitant to speak, naturally distrustful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. You can tell him. He's on our side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear your parents say they were going to hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody sees what Lucy sees at this moment. Edward glaring at her through the window. Lucy looks at Wayne, shakes he head. Wayne looks at Emily, case closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily watches in agony as the Sheridan family steps into elevator. Parent on each side, Lucy gives her one last pleading look then the elevator doors close and she's gon 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Wayne in the heat of an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't trust anybody. You think I made it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd do just about anything you had to do to help a child you thought was at risk. Here are the facts, Emily. They haven't laid a finger on her that we can tell. And we have no proof they intend to. Meanwhile on your desk right now are thirty-plus cases of actionable abuse. What about those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not giving up on her, Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are, you're leaving this alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look that says he means it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you can live with a dead child on your conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a little unfair, don't you think? I care about these kids as much as you do, but we can't go around yanking them out of their homes on a hunch. Parents, even bad ones, have rights, that's how the laws of this great land are written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily gives a resigned nod, backing away from him, from t job, all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's it? We let kids get killed until they rewrite the goddamn laws?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits before he can answer, doesn't want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective MIKE BARRON. Veteran of the force. Man of quiet faith. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-built silver-haired family man who played fullback Brigham Young. He's doing paperwork. Smiles warmly as Emi enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was just thinking about you, got a nice letter from Sandy Hutchinson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops Lucy's file on his desk. Whatever Barron was go to say is no longer relevant. Soberly, after a pause:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's sitting in front of me which means our good friend Wayne thinks it fails to meet the criteria for child endangerment and has told you in no uncertain terms to leave it alone...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise, surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to open the file. Barron stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Emily. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, I'm desperate here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tense beat. The need for privacy now apparent, Barron get up and closes his door. Sits down at his desk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how dear to my heart the work you do is, but the department doesn't pay me to stakeout potential child abusers. Last time almost cost me my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This girl heard her parents say they're going to send her to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sickening as that is, you're a part of the system that handles those situations, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The system is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you just need to let it work. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Jesus, I feel like I'm talking to Wayne. You don't want to get involved, fine, but don't bullshit me, I'm running out of people I respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. No bullshit. Give me evidence of a crime, I'll be all over it. Till then there's nothing I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blade of a circular saw SCREAMS through a pinewood bo spitting sawdust...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ten-pound hammer CRUSHES the head of a nail, sinking it CRUSHES another, CRUSHES another, the speed of the handiw conveying its urgency...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy peering into the basement through an air vent in the floor, vertical bands of light on her face. Edward hammer down below. He steps aside and we see what he's making...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensing Lucy's stare, he glances up over his shoulder. An Lucy ducks out of sight, breath held.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children waiting for the bus after school. Talking, laughing. Lucy stands apart, tired and solemn. The bus pulls up to the curb. As she goes to get on:

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns. Emily behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted you to know I haven't forgotten about you. I'm doing everything I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy hugs her, clinging for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I disappear will you come look for me? 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily holds her gaze, seeing the fear. Backing away, Lucy indicates the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go. They get mad when I miss the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy turns to go. Emily watches. Helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes her cell phone from her bag. Puts her number on spe dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything happens, call me, okay? Just press this. Don't let your parents know you have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tucks the cell phone in Lucy's coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get you out of there, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy boards the bus. Waves to Emily from a back window as drives away. Emily waves back, heart in her throat. Might be the last time she sees her alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sleepless night finds Emily slouched on her sofa, leavi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is Doug, here it comes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me, thought you might be up, um, anyway, call if you get this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hangs up. Clicks on the tv remote. Channel-surfs. World news. Cooking show. Home shopping network. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hip-hop music video. Watches it for a moment. Gangster wi a mic. Scantily-clad girls shaking their asses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Emily mutes the tv, picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late, I met someone else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A child's whisper.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Emily...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned but calm) Lucy? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm scared...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why are you scared, honey?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They're waiting to get me, I can hear them... I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you sorry?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm falling asleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, listen, I want you to go over and open the window. Can you do that? Lucy...?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (softly; drifting off) I'm sooorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, no, wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cell phone lying on the bed at Lucy's fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The illuminated screen casts an eerie glow on her SLEEPIN FACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily drops the phone. Moment of panic. Then a decision. Throws a coat on over her bed clothes. Grabs the phone again, dials a number in desperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, it's Emily, listen, that girl I told you about, I think she's in trouble - - yeah, I know what you said, but -- Mike, you're not listening --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily fumbles with her keys. Gets the right one in the do Opens it. Jumps in. Starts the engine. Peels off down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cell phone turns itself off, plunging the room into t darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In BLACK, we hear FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs. Down th hall. Stopping at the door. The knob turning. The click o the latch. The door opening. A shaft of light. Edward and Margaret peering in with frenzied anticipation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy is asleep. The time has come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily red-lines the tachometer, doing ninety down the freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, quietly, Edward descends the stairs with Lucy asl in his arms. Margaret in front of him, moving in tandem, holding a roll of duct tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the bottom. Margaret rushes ahead into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward carries Lucy toward the OLD GAS OVEN where Margare waits, holding open the door. 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delicately, cradling her head, Edward puts Lucy into the without waking her. But as he lifts the door, one of the metal hinges CREAKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy jolts awake with a SCREAM. Kicks open the door befor Edward can shut it. With animal terror she thrashes her w out onto the linoleum floor. Margaret throws a piece of d tape over her mouth, silencing her screams as Edward wres her back into the oven. But she kicks open the door again and the frantic struggle continues as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily's car lurches to a stop out front. As she jumps out Barron's pickup arrives. He joins her, a reluctant accomplice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saving her life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes up the walkway. Barron lagging a few steps behin eyeing the darkened house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily hears something inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, trusting her gut, starts pounding on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave her alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing Emily, Edward and Margaret intensify their effort jamming Lucy's legs inside the oven. The duct tape peels her mouth in the struggle and before the oven door slams she belts out one last desperate SCREAM. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly audible outside, it makes Barron jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barron pounds his big fist on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police, open up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barron rams his shoulder against the door, but it holds solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Lucy's screaming face through the oven window as Margaret cranks the temperature dial as high as it will g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside we see Edward and Margaret peering in as Lucy claws at the glass with her fingernails. Coughing as the fills the oven with a low hiss. We hear it ignite beneath her with a faint poof. The first shimmering waves of heat rising up, singeing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, hysterical, knowing they're too late:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door comes crashing down, kicked off its hinges Barron. Emily and he race in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take off toward the kitchen at the end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Barron rush in. Emily sees Lucy trapped inside oven. The sleeve of her pajamas catching fire. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward tries to fend Barron off. It's a mistake. Barron unleashes a devastating blow that sends him recoiling int the fridge so hard the back of his head leaves a visible in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily shoves Margaret aside and throws open the oven. Pul Lucy out onto the kitchen floor, swatting out her burning pajamas with a dish towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret grabs a steak knife and rushes at Emily, but Bar has her covered. Backhands Margaret so hard it spins her around fully before dropping her to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell's the matter with you people?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pajamas scorched, wild with terror, Lucy cries in great heaving sobs in Emily's arms. Reduced to tears herself, Emily keeps saying the same thing over and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotcha... I gotcha... I gotcha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shielding her from the sight of her parents: Margaret sprawled on the linoleum weeping. Edward slouched against the fridge, blood pouring down his shirt, his broken jaw hanging open like a man thinking wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward and Margaret holding hands at the defendant's tabl remorseless and defiant in their Sunday best. Among the m spectators we find Emily and Mike Barron. The STATE PROSECUTOR and PUBLIC DEFENDER addressing the JUDGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prosecution asks that you disallow an insanity defense. This was an act committed with premeditation, malice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, the egregiousness of the crime makes the competency question all the more relevant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I hereby order the defendants undergo psychiatric evaluation to determine their mental fitness for trial. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily rolls her eyes at Barron, some justice system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barron walks Emily to her car. She's outraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steal a pizza, San Quentin, try killing your kid, Freudian dream analysis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're gonna hate me for saying this, but my money's on crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they or did they not know what they were doing? That's the legal standard. They knew, they knew damn well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that simple sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops on a dime) Meaning what exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barron hesitates. He's crossing the line by telling her this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we brought them in that night they told Captain Lister... They think she's evil, some kind of demon spirit, minion of the devil or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's great - what is this, late- night cable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but that might be the world they're living in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy in a hospital bed, dressings on her hand. Emily's friend Doug sitting bedside. Child psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and what's the most important thing we talked about that you have to remember? 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my fault what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right and you know what? It's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods, not entirely convinced. Doug gives her a pat, crosses to the exit. At the door he runs into Emily. Shak his head, awed at what she did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is some seriously proactive social work happenin' there. You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm okay. How's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typical reaction, blames herself. We'll get there. I'm gonna put her in a group setting, see if I can get her to open up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group therapy for kids, what's that say about the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods - no kidding, heads off. Emily comes over and sit on Lucy's bed. Strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news. You get to leave here tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug said I might have to go to a state home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only for a few days, till we find a better place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I live with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sweetheart. That would never be allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's complicated, there's a whole process, I'm not even a foster parent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy gives a sad nod. Emily touches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No frills, purely functional housing. Emily comes up the steps with Lucy and knocks. The COORDINATOR answers. A ki but beleagured-looking woman of fifty, who is surprised t see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were supposed to call you. We don't have any rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a mixup with the dates. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily rolls her eyes. Lucy standing there holding a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windshield Lucy watches Emily on a pay phone outside a convenience store. Her back is to us but you ca see she's arguing with someone, scratching addresses off typed list with a ballpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily gets in and starts the car, putting on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, are you hungry? Let's get some lunch. What kind of food do you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nowhere for me to go is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heartbreaking. Emily can't lie. She turns off the engine and leans back with a sigh. Lucy's silence is a plea for rescue. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Lucy, it wouldn't work, I live in this tiny house, I... I'm sorry, I'm not mom material...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to be my mom. Just my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ten-year-old girl stranded at a convenience store, suit in her lap. Emily stares out the windshield, wrestling wi her conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a round table, Emily addresses the CHILD WELFARE PANEL six grave-faced administrators. Wayne is here, offering support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it feels like to be that age and be unwanted. It's terrifying. She needs to be with someone she trusts; she trusts me. So much of our time is spent negotiating red tape, I think if we just look at the situation - this one situation, this one child - it's clear what's best for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The head of the panel is a bloated bureaucrat in a polka blouse (NANCY).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is highly irregular and I'll tell you right now it makes me very uncomfortable. But since, Wayne, you've spoken so persuasively on Miss Jennings's behalf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily comes out and nods yes to Lucy who waits with a guardian. As they hug:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...I'm going to go against my better judgement and approve this petition for temporary custody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily walks Lucy through the house, showing her around, tidying things self-consciously. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to think of it as a glass-half- full situation. Kitchen. Bathroom. Fish. And here, is your room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in the doorway. A small office in which Emily h made space for a bureau and a bed. Professional books and backup case files pushed aside on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My family... well, I've met my dad twice and my mom's not a part of my life anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choosing her words) Sometimes people have kids and then decide they don't want to be parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath the measured tone Emily's pain is revealed, raw a untouchable, her entire life a rebellion against it. She opens Lucy's suitcase on the bed. Pauses, remembering something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy comes over to help unpack the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy in bed, sipping a cup of tea as Emily brushes her ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chamomile, when I get stressed out it helps me sleep. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods that it's good. Emily brushes her hair. A natur bond between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of this ever should have happened, if I could make it go away I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice moment for Emily. A rare triumph. She tucks Lucy in. Turns off the bedside light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right down the hall if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy settles. Emily pauses at the door, looks back at the lost child she's taken in, then closes the door halfway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark, abandoned. Emily's Volvo pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She eyes the house. It haunts her, the memory of what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SUDDEN KNOCK on the window makes her jump out of her se The guy there gestures a friendly sorry, didn't mean to s you. White shirt and tie. A COURT CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily signs a form as he unlocks the door, letting her in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to grab some of her things, might take me a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust ya, Em, make sure you lock it on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily closes the door, glances around the dark interior. Through a window she sees the Court Clerk drive off. She' alone. It's quiet, eerily still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes up the stairway. Slows, noticing something on th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FAINT SQUARE where a picture once was hung, the wallpap half tone darker underneath. More SQUARES farther up. A f nails still sticking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tattered lace curtains sway in a draft beside a bed with moth-eaten coverlet. Emily packs Lucy's spare clothes int dufflebag. Zips it and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exiting Lucy's room, she notes the door to Edward and Margaret's bedroom, at the far end of the hall, is slight AJAR. Succumbs to a natural curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door pushes open, Emily peering in. A sad little mast bedroom with old floral printed wallpaper and water stain the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She explores the room, inspecting various personal items aftershave, glasses, hair brush - looking for clues to th madness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ALARM CLOCK with a cracked crystal face. She picks it and it GOES OFF in her hand. Gives her a scare. She puts down. Sees something out the bedroom window. Steps closer Parts the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the backyard, by the garden shed, a long rectangular h has been dug. A SHALLOW GRAVE filling with leaves. Edward handiwork. Emily's seen enough, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But slows, noticing something odd as she comes back aroun the bed -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the wooden floor, hidden under a long runner rug. Emil peels back the rug and finds -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the floorboards leading toward the door. Something - t old oak bureau perhaps? - has been dragged repeatedly acr the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily comes over and looks behind the door and sees, on t back of it, something even more bizarre -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: screwed hastily, crookedly, into the wood. She closes the door. Slides-to the big heavy bolts -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauses. Looks again at the bureau. Slides it in front of the door, a wheelless caster bracket leaving another long scratch in the hardwood. And it's clear at this point wha the deadbolts and bureau add up to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily stares at it. Looks over at Edward and Margaret's b imagining them here behind this door. Slides the bureau aside. Opens the deadbolts. And as the door swings open s is looking straight down the hall at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily stares, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABUSED CHILDREN aged eight to thirteen sit in a circle of folding chairs. Lucy among them. Diego. Doug facilitating

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes when our parents aren't getting along it's better if they don't see each other for a while, that's what a `restraining order' does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily looks in, waiting with other parents. Lucy sees her the window and sneaks her a little wave. Emily smiles and holds up a hand that says, hi, hon. It's clear from these gestures how close they've gotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Doug walk together after session. Lucy talking other kids her age by the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's starting to come out of her shell. It's good, I just wish I thought it was me making the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily accepts the compliment. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went by the house. I think her mom and dad were barricading themselves in their room at night. How sick is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatred and fear are part of the same pathology - oh, but I forgot, you don't think they're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they part ways...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily pulls up in front of Lucy's school. Big moment for Lucy. New clothes. New haircut. New life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods, apprehensive, but she's ready to face it. Emil hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your new beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy gets out. Pauses on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, touched, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy goes up the walk. Emily watches her safely into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily draws grim looks as she crosses the common area. A pall hanging over the entire department. The first person she walks past says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne's looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second person: 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne wants to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes past Wayne's office. Empty. A coworker points over toward Emily's cubicle - he's there. She goes over. Wayne's inside, grave-faced, looking for a file. He finds on the shelf. A photo of eight-year-old DIEGO clipped ins the cover. The boy we met earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up with Diego?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne hesitates, wanting to spare her the bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we talk in my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know why yet, but... he killed his mother and father last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily stands there, jaw on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police perimeter around a small house in a tough low-in neighborhood. Cops and crime scene investigators on the scene. Local news media broadcasting live. A couple of ne choppers hovering overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily pulls up, jumps out of her car. Mike Barron waves o the uniformed officer who moves to intercept her as she c up the walkway to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you want to see this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an uncertain nod she follows him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Mike Barron come along the uncarpeted hallway. 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gets a tire iron from the garage, comes back inside, locks all the doors and windows, kills them in their sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The master bedroom. A bloodbath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to use dental records to identify the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily looks around, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eight-year-old did this? There's no way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there when they brought him in. Took three guys my size to subdue him. Kid was climbing the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barron turns to the window and - WHAM! - AN ATTACK DOG HI THE GLASS RIGHT IN FRONT OF HIS FACE. Barron recoils with yelp. Then, embarrassed, eyes the TRIO OF BATTLE-SCARRED BULLS prowling the chainlink-fenced backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just your average American family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and Barron come down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juvie lockup. And, no, I'm not taking you to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. I need to talk to him. Mike, please, I care about this kid. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego Martinez sitting alone in a holding cell. Confused. Scared. He sees Emily approaching and immediately breaks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily tells the cop at the cell door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me in. He won't hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop looks at Mike Barron who nods it's okay. The cop opens the cell. Emily enters. Diego looks up at her, shuddering with emotion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, gutted, nods yes. Diego buries his face in Emily's stomach and sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? Tell me what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed my mum and dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, devastated, trades looks with Barron through the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug tenderly consoles Emily. Has his arms around her. They're leaning against the railing, wind on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every family you sit down with every day of every week is a family in crisis. Those are your odds. That's the job you do. Trying to beat them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wipes away her tears. The hair from her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're one person, Em. You can't save the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know somebody you did save. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy on the beach below, walking barefoot at water's edge hem of her dress in her hands. Emily watches her and, finding solace in it, leans into Doug's embrace and close her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plaintive cries of seagulls overhead as Emily and Luc walk along the surf at sundown, Emily barefoot now as wel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods, putting on a brave face to spare Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just work. Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods okay. They walk on in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do it if it makes you sad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job? I don't know, I guess... I guess maybe I want to believe families can work, so I can have my own someday, I don't know - does that make sense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods, takes her hand. They walk off up the beach together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, days later, dressed for work, halves an omelet wit spatula and slides the halves onto two plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to other room) Breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no answer. Emily goes to get her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, breakfa--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees Lucy hide something under her pillow. Emily comes ov brow arched, playful. 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let me see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy guiltily eyes the floor. Emily lifts the pillow. Underneath it is a photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Lucy, then at the filing cabinet from which was taken. More surprised than upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went through my things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I wanted to know what happened to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disarming sincerity. Emily's gaze falls to the photo. Qui moment. She sits down on the bed with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods, lost in the image. It's a photo that captures her entire childhood. Emily and her mother sitting on the steps of a house, together but apart, like a lost child t sat down next to a pretty stranger who hasn't yet noticed her. Emily's ten-year-old face shows the quiet sadness of the disconnect. Reminds you of a child from her caseload.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She used to just leave, she'd just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I never knew when she was coming back, or if she was... I used to think it was my fault and I would try so hard when she got home to be good, do everything I could think of, so she'd think I was `special' and stay next time or take me with her, but... it didn't matter, she'd always go away again, that's how it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily fights her emotions and, practiced at the task, win Lucy sits beside her on the bed. Understands her deeply. Linked by their pasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was your dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone, he left before I was born. First time I met him I was like thirteen. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I had all these things I was gonna say. Angry things I'd thought of and kind of memorized. And um.... And then I met him and I wasn't angry, I was just sad and I told him... (pauses, raw emotion) I said, I love you, even if you don't love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily smiles a pained smile and then buries the memory. Lucy, a portrait of contrition:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... No, I'm not mad at you. (puts her arm around her) But I need you not to do that again, okay? Go through my private things without asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods okay. Emily moves on, with a loving touch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omelet's getting cold. Better hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy exits. Emily eyes the photo a moment longer then sta and puts it away in the filing cabinet. She pauses, feeli exposed, and turns the little key to lock the drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily stops at her cubicle, registering a surprise. Wayne handing her case files to three COWORKERS. Awkward moment for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need another set of eyes to go over them, make sure we haven't missed anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, to make sure I haven't missed anything else? 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a legal thing. You'll have them back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit. She goes in and stares at the BARE SHELF above her desk. Her caseload gone. More than an insult. Everything she cares about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pink phone message on her keyboard. She picks it up: Mi Barron called. Important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newspaper headline: "INSANITY DEFENSE FOR GLENDALE COUPLE MUGSHOTS of Edward and Margaret below. The morning editio folded on a table between Barron and Emily. They're drink coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch, six months, their lawyer will hire some expert to say they're rehabbed and they'll sue for custody when they get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not going back there, I'll take her out of state before I let them near her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear you say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily knows she's misspoken, but lets it stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to talk about something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barron nods, sips his coffee, a bit uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pulled the Martinezes' phone records. They got a call that night before the murders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, the call came from your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not accusing you of anything, I just need to know what was said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible. I might have called the week before...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking to you as a friend here, you know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not hear me? I'm telling you, Mike, as a friend, I did not call that family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who did? Go find the guy who broke in and just happened to dial the number of a kid whose case you handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily starts to say something, but stops as a confounding realization comes to her. And then to Barron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy sits on the sofa studying a photo of Diego. Emily si beside her, her advocate. Barron opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in my group... (puts down photo) ...why, did something happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods yes. Barron, gently, mindful of Lucy's age:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to figure out why. He got a call Thursday night from this number. I'm just wondering if he might have said anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't call him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy shakes her head. Barron nods okay, then, speaking to her as a father might his own daughter: 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, it's hard sometimes to tell the truth, but I know you will because you're a good little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My backup files are in your room. Diego's is in there. Maybe you got curious and went through some, dialed a number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't me, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete innocence. Emily nods okay, wanting to believe, remembering the stolen photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The call was at 2 am, are you ever up that late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ever up that late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, she said no. Maybe someone made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barron reads Emily's posture and disengages, stands to go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe so. Night, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exiting, Barron tells Emily as gently as possible:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And goes down the steps. Emily closes the door. Turns around and there's Lucy. Uncomfortably close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe me? 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy hugs her and Emily hugs her back, but she's still thinking about what Barron said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PHOTO of Emily and Diego tacked to the corkboard panel beside her desk. Emily sits contemplating it. Her gaze go from the photo to the BARE SHELF above her desk. Her caseload is still missing. This is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily walks in, power pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me back my cases or fire me. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne, caught unprepared, eating a doughnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caseload restored, Emily is multi-tasking, opening mail, sorting backlogged paperwork, talking on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if it's a hairline fracture, he broke her arm, I don't want him back in that house. He what? He found Christ? When? That recently? Uh huh. Well he should have found Him sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hangs up. Doug leans in the doorway, drops a manila envel in her in-box. And a computer printout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy of the Sheridans' psych evals for the file. And the cognitive profile Lucy did for me the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Lucy's profile) How's it look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normal. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But his tone suggests otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to beg or are you gonna tell me what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to beg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming from an environment like that, testing this normal is a bit abnormal, if that makes any sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's `abnormally normal'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she faked it, gave the answers she thought she should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would she do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's ashamed of who she is. Ashamed of how she feels. Afraid nobody would want her if they saw the real her. (off Emily's reaction) It's no big deal, it just means I might have to push her a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I know, I just... The Martinezes' got a call Thursday night. From my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ask her about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said she didn't. Mike thinks she's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Bring her in after work, I'll do a one-on-one. I wanted to talk to her about this anyway. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He departs. Emily, alone in her cubicle, scans the test results with growing concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego eating macaroni and cheese from a jailhouse tray. Emily sets a folded blanket on the bed as she sits down t talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got you an extra in case it gets cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego nods without looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to ask you something... about the night it happened... did you get a call, really late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego stops eating. Stares at his food. Shakes his head n warily, like someone might be listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head no. Still staring at his food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego, I know you did, they called from my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego puts down his fork, his fear obvious now, his breat quick and shallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? What's scaring you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Emily, terrified, starts HYPERVENTILATING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily tries to calm the panicked boy as he gasps for air, horrible WHEEZING sound in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay... slow breaths... you'll be okay... (yelling down hall) Can somebody help us down here?! 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little two-bed infirmary with unpainted cinder block wa Diego in bed on an IV drip. Emily talking to a NURSE by t check-in desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked to see you before you left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily comes over to Diego's bed. He holds her gaze in silence, a secret he's afraid to tell. Emily speaks at a whisper, as if to make the truth less frightening:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who called you? Was it Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego's PULSE ACCELERATES on the EKG monitor. He gives a trembling nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she say something to you? Something that scared you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego replies in Spanish, barely discernible, his throat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El dijo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `El' dijo? What do you mean, `He said'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego looks at her, confused, terrified. His RACING PULSE jagged green line above the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Era un hombre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chill goes through Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego gives another trembling nod. Emily beside him, baff and a bit scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After hours, the office is empty, half lit and eerily sti Emily is photocopying at a work station, haunted by what Diego said, the harsh upward light accentuating her tense features. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CYCLICAL SQUEAKING NOISE we hear is Lucy, in Emily's cubicle in the b.g., turning herself in circles on the of chair. Something very creepy about the disappearance and reappearance of that pale watchful face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished, Emily walks back to her cubicle, thrown by the sight of Lucy spinning in the chair, walking head-on into that eerie intermittent gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: working...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, unnerved, enters the cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, photocopying isn't much fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy stops turning, stares at her, sensing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy just stares. Doug appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock, knock. Sorry I'm late, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready, kiddo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods and gets up from the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead down, I'll be right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy heads down the hall to the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is weird. Diego said it was Lucy that called, but he called her a he, he said it was a man. 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face - what? Emily nods yes. Doug's brow arches then furrows. He turns and heads down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sits opposite Lucy at the table, keeps it easygoing despite what he's just been told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of your classmates giving you a hard time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they've been nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not really what you want to talk about, is it, Doug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward pause. Awkward smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens his file. Takes out her cognitive assessment profil Lays it flat on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Question 16a, are you afraid of the dark? You answered `no'. Question 16b, are you afraid of being alone? `No'. 16c, are afraid of your parents? `No'. You answered `no' to everything in that section. I think some of those should have been yesses. Everybody is afraid of something. Working through our fears, conquering them, is how we get better. So I want you to tell me... What scares you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy steeples her fingers and rests her chin on top, rega Doug with a look of frank appraisal. It is the face of a child, but behind those eyes there is a keen intelligence 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what scares me if you tell me what scares you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug did not see this coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough. When I was twelve I was climbing a tree and I accidentally put my hand through a giant hornets' nest. They didn't like it. I got stung over a hundred times. They had to rush me to the hospital. I've been afraid of hornets ever since. Don't climb many trees either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has fears. Now, what scares you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scare yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, what about yourself scares you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have bad thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People in general or certain people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certain people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have bad thoughts about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there something I said or did that upset you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) It's just the way you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facile? (she nods yes) Do you even know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easily comprehended. Often lacking sincerity or depth. You're smug, too. Want me to tell you what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead silence. Doug skewered by a ten-year-old. A boyish shyness emerges, a relic from his own youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if, um, if I seemed `smug' or `facile' I want to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a grown up, it's embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we talk about school now? My grades are getting a lot better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting until Lucy is out of earshot down the hall, Doug confers with Emily by the water cooler. He's sweating, shaken by the encounter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talked to a lot of ten-year-olds, I don't think I've ever felt like that before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Threatened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a specialist, I'll call him in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do with her in the meantime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug pauses, no idea, smiles an eerie smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let her get in your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
